paragraphs.text: High School: Islamic vocabulary lesson part of Common Core standards.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Parents in Farmville, North Carolina want to know why their children were given a Common Core vocabulary assignment in an English class that promoted the Prophet Muhammad and the Islamic faith
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "It really caught me off guard," a Farmville Central High School student who was in the class told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "If we are not allowed to talk about any other religions in school - how is this appropriate?"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The Islamic vocabulary worksheet was assigned to seniors
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "I was reading it and it caught me off guard," the student told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "I just looked at it and knew something was not right- so I emailed the pages to my mom."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "In the following exercises, you will have the opportunity to expand your vocabulary by reading about Muhammad and the Islamic word," the worksheet read
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The lesson used words like astute, conducive, erratic, mosque, pastoral, and zenith in sentences about the Islamic faith
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: CLICK HERE
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: TO FOLLOW TODD ON FACEBOOK FOR CONSERVATIVE CONVERSATION!
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: "The zenith of any Muslim's life is a trip to Mecca," one sentence read
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: For "erratic," the lesson included this statement:"The responses to Muhammad's teachings were at first erratic. Some people responded favorably, while other resisted his claim that 'there is no God but Allah and Muhammad his Prophet."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Another section required students to complete a sentence
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "There are such vast numbers of people who are anxious to spread the Muslim faith that it would be impossible to give a(n)___ amount."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: I spoke to one parent who asked not to be identified
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: She was extremely troubled by what her child was exposed to in the classroom
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "What if right after Pearl Harbor our educational system was talking about how great the Japanese emperor was?" the parent asked
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "What if during the Cold War our educational system was telling students how wonderful Russia was?"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The parent said the material was classwork disguised as Islamic propaganda
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "It's very shocking," she said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "I just told my daughter to read it as if it's fiction. It's no different than another of fictional book you've read."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: A spokesman for Pitt County Schools defended the lesson
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: noting that it came from a state-adopted supplemental workbook and met the "Common Core standards for English Language Arts."
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "The course is designed to accompany the world literature text, which emphasizes culture in literature," the statement read
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The problem is it's emphasizing a specific culture and religion
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the school district acknowledged there were concerns "related to the religious nature of sentences providing vocabulary words in context."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Our school system understands all concerns related to proselytizing, and there is no place for it in our instruction," the statement goes on to say
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "However, this particular lesson was one of many the students in this class have had and will have that expose them to the various religions and how they shape cultures throughout the world."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: I asked the school district to provide me with a copy of vocabulary worksheets that promoted the Jewish, Hindu and Christian faiths
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The school district did not reply
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I also asked for the past or future dates when the students would be given those vocabulary worksheets
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The school district has yet to reply
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The student I spoke with told me they have not had any other assignments dealing with religion- other than the one about Islam
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Why is that not surprising?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Based on its official statement, Pitt County Schools seems confident that the vocabulary lessons are in compliance with three Common Core standards related to literacy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you want to look up those standards
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: reference CCSSELA- Literary L11-12.4. A, 12.4. D and 12.6
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Since the Common Core folks seem to be infatuated with sentence completion - let me try one out on them
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Use "Islamic" and "proselytizing" in the following sentence
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Somebody got their ____ hand caught in the ____ cookie jar
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: UPDATE
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I asked the school district if there had been similar vocabulary assignments about Judaism, Christianity or other religions
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I also asked for the exact dates of those assignments
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Here's the reply I received from the school district
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "The class recently finished reading Night by Elie Wiesel
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: As part of the study of this book, students were exposed to Judaism
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: I'm told that one of the next couple of lessons that will be taught in this class includes an examination of Psalm 23 as part of the lesson
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Additionally
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the workbook in question has another vocabulary lesson with words used in a passage about India's three great beliefs (Hinduism, Jainism, Buddhism)
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Keep in mind that this workbook is just one of numerous resources used in the course
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Students are exposed to various cultures, values, and beliefs through the reading of multiple types of literature, but teachers certainly aren't advocating for any of them."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Notice how the school district dodged my question?
paragraphs.label: assumption
